description: Dive into "Capturing Athens: Iconic Photo Adventures" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Capturing Athens: Iconic Photo Adventures

places.generalDescription: The Parthenon, a restored ancient temple with iconic Doric columns dating back to 447 BC, is a must-see landmark on the archaeological site in Athens. Visitors can explore major historical and archaeological sites such as the Acropolis, the renowned museum, and other significant cultural museums like the Benaki Museum of Islamic Art and the Museum of Cycladic Art. In addition to historical sites, Athens offers vibrant neighborhoods and pedestrian streets for visitors to explore.

sources.snippet: These will guide you to the magnificent Acropolis, the highlight of the city of Athens with the imposing buildings of Parthenon, the Erechtheion, Propylaea, and the Temple of Nike, as you explore the highest hill of the city. This is the best time to have your camera ready and fill those memory cards with magnificent panoramic views of Athens from the top scenic location spots like Filoppapos, Mars, and Pnyx.
sources.shortName: Best photo spots in Athens

sources.snippet: Let‚Äôs start the list of the most Instagrammable places in Athens with the most iconic photo spot in the city, the Parthenon. Sitting atop the Acropolis, this breathtaking ancient Greek temple dominates the city‚Äôs skyline and can be seen from practically anywhere. The temple is believed to have been built during the 5th century and is dedicated to the Goddess of Athena Parthenos.
sources.shortName: 14 Epic Athens Instagram Spots You Can‚Äôt Miss

sources.snippet: The Parthenon is a former temple on the Acropolis of Athens dedicated to the goddess Athena, the city‚Äôs patron. Built in 480 BC, it was the centre of government, banking and religion for the Ancient Greeks; today it is a historically significant example of classical art and architecture. Perched high on the hill, it overlooks the city and is visible for miles around.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Athens

sources.snippet: Obviously the most famous photo spot in Athens is the Acropolis ‚Äì and in particular the Parthenon ‚Äì so you do not want to skip this photo spot. Because it is so famous, it gets really crowded at the Acropolis, so it‚Äôs best to visit at opening time. There are two entrances to the Acropolis, but the main entrance is a much shorter walk to the Parthenon.
sources.shortName: Best photo spots in Athens (Greece)

sources.snippet: At 512 feet tall, the Parthenon is one of the oldest sights in the world. It is actually located on a rocky outcrop above the city of Athens. It‚Äôs a very popular tourist spot, aim to get their early to avoid crowds so you can get a clear picture of just you and the beautiful architecture.
sources.shortName: The Best Instagram spots in Athens

sources.snippet: One of the best Instagram photo spots in Athens is the Parthenon on the Acropolis!. The Parthenon is an ancient and famous temple dedicated to the goddess Athena (from which the city derives its name). After a pretty long climb, you will reach this point.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagram Photo Spots in Athens

places.name: Parthenon

reviews.text:
It's getting sympathetically restored extremely slowly. In fact, some of the work previously done by others has been found to be wrong and needs redoing. And therefore is even slower. I doubt I'll see it finished in my lifetime.

There's a water machine at the bottom and both a machine and tap at the top. Walking this is for able bodied people only. There are many steps. Also, it's incredibly crowded, especially at the main entrance near the top (a deliberate design feature).

Note that good shoes are essential. At the top, when you leave the path, the surface is full of super polished marble. Uneven and very slippy. Be careful.

If you can book a proper tour, the insights are 100% worth it.

Another amazing piece of history that we were keen to visit!

Parthenon is an amazing wonder of the world, glimpse in to the past as you navigate the beautiful site that is clearly marked and easy to access for all.

Plenty of steps, but your on top of the world once close to the towering stone and marble pillars.

It's ‚Ç¨30 euro for a ticket either online or at the kiosk. If you arrive around 10/11am you will join a queue.

Warning ‚ÄºÔ∏èbe careful of the touts selling tickets who appear every know and again, they will offer 9 tickets at ‚Ç¨30 each once you agree they thrust the ticket in your hand and pull you out the queue‚Ä¶. They will disappear to sell the rest of the tickets then reappear and the price is now ‚Ç¨60 euro! ‚Ç¨30 for the ticket and ‚Ç¨30 for them to guide‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

Make sure you take a drink as it's a long walk, I wouldn't recommend anyone that struggles with steps or requires a scooter or mobility buggy as it's super rough in places.

We spent around 2.5 hrs and honestly could have spent more time! Photos are always good but see it in person if you can as it's just amazing!
Very hot! Early in the morning or late in the evening best time to go. Our ticket was 6:00 pm-7:30 pm the sunsets are worth admission.

places.generalDescription: The Acropolis of Athens is an iconic 5th-century B.C. temple complex located on a rocky hilltop in Athens, currently undergoing restoration. Visitors can explore this historic site by purchasing a Special Ticket Package that includes access to other nearby attractions like the Ancient Agora, Temple of Hephaestus, and Hadrian's Library. Additionally, tourists can enjoy stunning views of the Acropolis from retro-chic design hotels situated near the Parthenon's east gate and the Acropolis Museum.

sources.snippet: It‚Äôs one of the world‚Äôs greatest treasures and the Acropolis is an Athens iconic. The city sits under the watchful eye of the Parthenon, the ancient temple, the Erechtion, has beautiful stonework and the stunning theatre, the Odeon of Herodes Atticus, are all photo worthy. When to visit: Athens is very busy during peak season with the Acropolis being the city‚Äôs most visited site.
sources.siteName: The Whole World Is A Playground
sources.shortName: 13 Best Photo Locations in Athens (2024)

sources.snippet: A visit to Athens would not be complete with a visit to the Acropolis. And since it is located smack in the city center, you get one of the best views of Athens right from this point. Enjoy the view of the Parthenon, over the Ancient Agora, the slopes of the Acropolis, the Acropolis Museum, and the hills mentioned earlier in this article.
sources.shortName: Best Views of Athens and the Acropolis: 9 Great Spots to Try

sources.snippet: Any list of things to do in Athens would be incomplete without its most famous sight: the Acropolis. At the center of downtown Athens, it‚Äôs just as amazing and breathtaking as it seems. In fact, this hill has an almost spiritual quality, one that somehow isn‚Äôt dampened by the stark contrast of modern-day times and its ancient beginnings.
sources.shortName: An Instagrammer‚Äôs Guide to Athens ‚Äì Passion Passport

sources.snippet: Athens‚Äô most emblematic landmark, the Acropolis towers over the Greek capital from its perch at an altitude of 500 feet. It teems with history and there are several angles from where you can snap: up high, down low, up close, from afar. If you visit the site, the sweeping panoramas of the city from above are also worth capturing.
sources.shortName: 10 of the most Instagrammable Places in Athens

sources.snippet: The Acropolis is the most famous historical site in Greece, and one of the most famous attractions in the world. Because it‚Äôs such a popular tourist destination, over 6 million people visit Athens every year. There are 3 landmarks that are very instagrammable at the Acropolis.

places.name: Acropolis of Athens

reviews.text: It is hard to describe this magical place, lifetime experience. Location is a rocky hill above the Athens. Always have water with you because it's very very hot in Athens especially when you are climbing to Acropolis. Beautiful place, if you are in this part of Greece don't miss it. We are breathing Ancient Greece here. Spectacular views.

Beautiful. I went in the afternoon so it was super warm.. But I bought my ticket via the official website days before and just had to wait until it was the time on the ticket and could walk in easily! It is busy while waiting but every hour a whole group goes up!

Certainly an awe inspiring place of history.  Going with a tour is highly recommended for the information and the guidance - we would have missed so many nuances without.....  go early and enjoy the sunrise!

places.generalDescription: The Acropolis Museum, a modern glass and steel structure, has been open to the public since 2009. Its design allows for stunning views of the Parthenon from almost every corner. The museum showcases artifacts unearthed around the citadel, offering insight into the culture and daily life of ancient Greek civilizations. While there is debate about whether certain exhibits should be returned to Greece, visitors can appreciate beautifully crafted copies in place of the originals.

sources.snippet: The Acropolis Museum is great to visit to see some ancient artifacts, but it‚Äôs also a great Instagram spot. Especially the spot where I took this picture, right at the entrance. Because of the reflective floor you can work great with lines and symmetry.
sources.shortName: Instagram spots in Athens

sources.snippet: For that reason, it's definitely worth taking some photos there. But besides that, it's also one of the best museums in Athens. I'd highly recommend going there and have a look at all the ancient objects!
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagram Photo Spots in Athens

places.name: Acropolis Museum

reviews.text:
I can highly recommend it to everyone it's very interesting, and you'll need at least 3‚Äì5 hours to go through it all. The ticket costs around ‚Ç¨20. The place is pleasantly air-conditioned and has clean, proper restrooms.

Interesting fact: even if you're a student, you can't use your student ID if you're over 25. There were huge lines at the entrance for everything. But it's worth the wait absolutely incredible.

The Acropolis Museum is a must-visit when exploring Athens. Located just a short walk from the Acropolis itself, this modern museum beautifully showcases artifacts excavated from the sacred rock and its surrounding slopes. The design of the building is impressive, with plenty of natural light and a transparent floor that allows you to see ancient ruins beneath the museum.

Inside, the exhibits are thoughtfully arranged, offering a clear and engaging narrative of the ancient civilization that once thrived here. Highlights include stunning sculptures from the Parthenon, intricate pottery, and statues that tell stories of mythology and daily life.

The museum is very well organized, making it easy to follow even for those new to ancient history. Interactive displays and multilingual information panels enhance the visitor experience. The museum also houses a lovely caf√© with views of the Acropolis, perfect for relaxing after your tour.

Entry lines can be long, especially during peak season, but the staff is efficient and helpful, and tickets can be bought online to save time. The museum is wheelchair accessible and has facilities that make it suitable for families and visitors of all ages.

If you want to deepen your understanding of Athens and its ancient past, the Acropolis Museum offers an unforgettable experience that perfectly complements your visit to the historic Acropolis site.

‚ÄãI visited the Acropolis Museum in Athens and the experience was absolutely incredible! The building's architecture is simply breathtaking and its beauty is fascinating. I loved that the museum is built directly on top of ruins, which are visible through the transparent floors, creating a unique connection to history. The collections are vast and beautifully presented, and the view from the top floor is breathtaking. What's more, tickets are free for young people under 25 from EU countries upon presentation of an ID card. It's an unmissable visit for history buffs.

places.generalDescription: The Odeon of Herodes Atticus, a restored stone theater constructed in 161 CE, hosts concerts and performances. It is historically significant as the site of the first recorded victory in theatrical competitions by Thespis in 534 BC. Thespis, a renowned performer of ancient Greece, is credited with being the first actor to play his own character on stage rather than relying solely on the choir for storytelling.

sources.snippet: After entering the ticketed entrance area of the Acropolis, you can visit the Herodes Atticus Odeon. There is a side path from the main walkway up to the Acropolis, with a theater view. The ancient theater, which was built during the Roman period, is still in use today, hosting some of the Athens Festival's best musical performances in the world over the last 60 years since its re-opening in modern times, including Nana Mouskouri, Luciano Pavarotti, and Frank Sinatra.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Athens

sources.snippet: This hill is located at the foot of the famous Acropolis and has some of the best views of it, in my opinion. From this angle, you are not able to directly see the Parthenon, but have a view towards the ‚ÄúBeul√© Gate‚Äù which is the entrance from which you enter into the Acropolis to see the Parthenon. And if you look to your left in the far distance you are able to see the top of the ‚ÄúEretteo‚Äù, which honours Athena and Poseidon.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Locations in Athens, Greece

sources.snippet: While you get to see the Odeon from the Acropolis, it deserves a separate mention on this list because it is still used as a concert venue. If at all possible, time your stay in Athens to include an open-air performance in this ancient theater. It‚Äôs forbidden to take photos of the actual performances, but perhaps you can manage to get a good shot before it starts.
sources.shortName: Top 29 Excellent Instagram Spots in Athens

sources.snippet: During daytime, the best aerial view (and selfie spot) is from the Acropolis, as it remains close to the public. However, in summer, (around June to early October) concerts and performances are held here in the evening. And I highly recommend this especially during the full moon.
sources.shortName: INSTAGRAM SPOTS IN ATHENS APART FROM THE ACROPOLIS

sources.snippet: Located further down the Dionysiou Areopagitou street, this is an ancient theater that is still used to this day. You can find some cool performances here as well as excellent acoustics. You are also able to see the Acropolis from here which makes for a fun picture.

places.name: Odeon of Herodes Atticus

reviews.text:
Majestic and unforgettable ‚Äì a true masterpiece of ancient architecture

The Odeon of Herodes Atticus is an absolute highlight when visiting Athens. Standing in this beautifully preserved ancient amphitheater is a truly humbling experience. The architectural details, the semi-circular seating, and the grand backdrop of the stone fa√ßade are simply breathtaking.

It's incredible to imagine the performances that once took place here ‚Äì and even more amazing that the venue still hosts concerts and cultural events today. The views from the upper levels are spectacular, offering a panoramic glance over the city and surrounding hills.

Whether you're passionate about history, architecture, or just looking for an inspiring place to visit, this is a must-see. The combination of cultural richness and scenic beauty is unbeatable.

Highly recommended ‚Äì you'll leave with goosebumps and a deep appreciation for ancient Greek civilization.

(Photos included speak for themselves ‚Äì this place is extraordinary!)

Iconic amphitheater makes for a stunning venue. If you're in Athens as a tourist book tickets to whatever is on here during your stay and go, you won't regret it. Be wary of the steep steps to get to the seats, take your time and be careful. Sitting here amongst the crowd is a wonderful experience.

You can see the seating areas in the lower part of the Acropolis theater. The seats of the city's notables are in a certain way. There is a security wall between the seats and the area. There is a wall built to ensure safety during shows with dangerous animals. It is a magnificent theater in very good condition.

places.generalDescription: The Ancient Agora of Athens is a significant historical site located northwest of the Acropolis. It served as a meeting place for the city council and local residents, playing a pivotal role in the early days of democracy. The Stoa of Attalos, an impressive marble structure built in 159 BC, stands as a testament to its rich history. This large square was not only an administrative and political center but also a hub for cultural and commercial activities dating back to the 6th century BC.

sources.snippet: Though it's a haven of calm today, the Agora was a clamorous place in classical Athens, being the chief marketplace area as a well as a meeting point and place of community significance, too. Evocative ruins are everywhere, with the Areopagus hill and Acropolis looming just above. Standouts include the Hephaisteion, also known as the Temple of Hephaestus and one of the best-preserved ancient Greek temples in the world, and the reconstructed Stoa of Attalos, now a museum with great exhibits relating to Athenian democracy.
sources.shortName: 10 of the Most Instagrammable Places in Athens
17 Best Photo Spots in Athens: Most Beautiful Places + Map

sources.snippet: The Ancient Agora is one of the most important sites in Athens, so make sure to include this place in your Athens itinerary. reviews.text: We visited midday and had an amazing experience-no lines, no waiting. We walked right in and were able to explore freely. The area is beautiful and perfect for taking photos. It's definitely a cool spot to bring someone special, hang out, and even take time to read up on the local landmarks and museum exhibits. Highly recommend if you're in the area!

Its about time we attended this site. In all the years we have visited Athens, we never made it to come here.  It was great to see the other Acropolis that is in better condition than the main one that we all know about.  The whole site is excellent.  A must visit

places.generalDescription: The Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center is a modern and inspiring cultural hub in Athens. It houses the Greek National Opera and the National Library of Greece, surrounded by expansive landscaped gardens. Renzo Piano's visionary design transformed a once barren wasteland into a lush hill offering breathtaking views of the city and the Aegean Sea. The center hosts cultural performances, art exhibitions, and provides a tranquil urban oasis for visitors.

sources.snippet: At the southern suburbs of Athens, in Kallithea, stands the stunning Cultural Center of the Stavros Niarchos foundation, which has become a popular destination for instagrammers!. The combination of modern architecture, facilities and the alluring garden make this place one of Athens‚Äô best instagram spots. From the top of the building one can enjoy a panoramic view of the entire city and if you visit during the sunset the sparkling lights will be the perfect set for stunning Instagram photos!
sources.shortName: #Athens: 10 Insta-perfect spots in Athens

sources.snippet: Another excellent photo location in Athens is the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center (SNFCC), combining views of modern architecture and nature. Its garden is a lush landscape with a wide variety of trees, plants and herbs that flourish in the Mediterranean soil. The new National Library is housed there, as well as the new National Opera.
sources.shortName: The Top 30 Photo Locations in Athens

sources.snippet: Many of the spots on this list of instagrammable places in Athens are historical sites. Not the Stavros Niarchos cultural center. This is the exact opposite.

places.name: Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center (SNFCC)

reviews.text:
Best Panoramic Views in Athens? Modern Athens & Breathtaking Views ‚Äì A Must-See!

Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center (SNFCC) is one of the most impressive places in Athens ‚Äì a modern cultural hub that combines stunning architecture, green spaces, and some of the best panoramic views over the city and the sea. Designed by world-renowned architect Renzo Piano, this space brings together the National Library of Greece, the Greek National Opera, and an expansive public park.

It's perfect for a quiet walk, enjoying the view from the rooftop terrace, or just relaxing with friends and family. The project also focuses on sustainability, with solar panels, natural ventilation, and water-saving systems.

Whether you're a culture lover, nature seeker, or view-chaser ‚Äì this place is a must-visit in Athens!

We had such a memorable day at the SNFCC - truly one of the best spots in Athens for families, culture lovers, and anyone who appreciates beautiful spaces. My kids were thrilled with the wide open park areas, interactive fountains, and bike paths. There's plenty of space to run around and play safely, and the atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming.

One of the absolute highlights for me was the National Library of Greece. The space is stunning - especially the ‚ÄúBook Castle,‚Äù a massive glass tower filled with books that feels like something out of a movie. The reading areas are quiet, modern, and full of natural light, with panoramic views of the sea from the top floor. I could've spent hours there just reading or taking in the view.

We ended our visit with a coffee by the canal and watched the sunset - it was the perfect end to a perfect day. Whether you're with kids, on your own, or visiting Athens for the first time, this place is a must. It offers nature, culture, and peace all in one. We'll definitely be back!

A great addition to the Athens cultural scene - and the coastline too. Marvelous park, stunning architecture. The National Library space is very welcoming, with plenty of natural light, and it was so wonderful to see it very busy. The 'living room' upstairs offers a great relaxing space with a variety of interesting books and amazing views of the city and the sea. Absolutely worth a visit!

places.generalDescription: The Athens National Garden is a historic park featuring native and exotic plants, as well as archaeological remains and a children's library. Situated on the south coast of Attica, it offers a peaceful atmosphere with secluded romantic corners. The garden is just one of many must-see sites in Athens, including the Acropolis, Mount Parnitha National Park, Diomidous Botanical Garden, Monastiraki Flea Market, and more.

sources.snippet: Continuing your Athens sightseeing Tour around the city, don‚Äôt miss out on taking your photos of other major Athens sites, including the Greek Parliament, the Syntagma square, the National Garden, the St. Paul‚Äôs Church, the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, the Catholic Cathedral, the Schliemann‚Äôs House, the University of Athens, the Academy of Athens, and the National Library. However, we do suggest a photo stop at Panathinaiko Stadium where the first Olympic Games took place in 1896, as It is the only stadium built out of white marble. For more majestic images of breathtaking Athenian views you can take our Cape Sounio Half Day Afternoon Tour.
sources.shortName: Best photo spots in Athens

sources.snippet: Escape the hustle and bustle of the city at the National Garden, a tranquil oasis in central Athens. With its lush greenery, winding paths, and resident peacocks, this park offers a peaceful setting for your photoshoot. Whether you‚Äôre a professional photographer or just looking to capture some Instagram-worthy shots, these locations in Athens are sure to inspire your creativity and leave you with stunning images to cherish for years to come.

places.name: Athens National Garden

reviews.text: We enjoyed visiting the National Garden during the day. Some sections of the walk offer shade, so there's no need to worry if you go during daylight hours. The place is nice and quiet, and enjoying nature there was truly pleasant. You'll also find puddles with turtles and fish, as well as a playground for the kids. There is a restrooms near the entrance.

This should be part of any tourist tour.  It's hard to describe such a beautifully green space in the middle of the city.  Pathways are clean and easy to walk.  We had no plans going in and did not have a set time to visit.  This might be the way to properly visit as we didn't rush ourselves and had time to enjoy a beer in the gardens as well.

There are maps everywhere so it's almost impossible to get lost even without any knowledge of the area.

Nice spot with a few animals as well, great for the kids.

We entered from one end, exited on the other side, went back in and finished our tour.  Definitely worth stopping by for a visit.

Athens National Garden is spectacular.  We spent a couple of hours meandering through.  There are many species of trees, some really large and old.  I am sure it is very beautiful in May and June with many types of flowers and bushes blooming.  There is a great children's playground and library.  There is a zoo type area with a few animals and lots of birds.  There are many nesting parrots in the trees above this area.  They have built very large communal nests.  There is a pond with ducks and geese.  There is also a small pool with turtles.  You can also see Roman ruins and a mosaic floor that was discovered as the garden was established.  You find maps throughout the park to indicate where you are.  There are also benches throughout the garden.  Most of the garden is shaded which is wonderful on a hot summer day.  I didn't see any public restrooms.

places.generalDescription: The National Archaeological Museum in Athens is a neoclassical treasure trove of ancient Greek art and artifacts, showcasing sculptures, metalwork, vases, and jewelry that span thousands of years. It offers a comprehensive journey through Greece's rich cultural heritage with exhibits appealing to history buffs, art enthusiasts, families, and curious travelers. Visitors can take advantage of guided tours and audio guides for a deeper insight into the significance of the artifacts.

sources.snippet: Go to the National Archaeological Museum of Athens for a modern version of the classical Greek architecture. The museum exhibits a diverse collection of ancient statues but the building itself is the true beauty here. Tall, strong pillars with a tympan where the sun kisses the golden statues while the wind brings the flag to life.
sources.shortName: The most photo worthy spots in Athens

places.name: National Archaeological Museum

reviews.text:
Acropolis Museum ‚Äì The Perfect Partner to the Acropolis

We visited the Acropolis Museum as a group of four: two adults and two kids (17 and 11). A nice surprise - kids under 18 get in for free! Adults pay about ‚Ç¨12 each, so our total was just ‚Ç¨24 - very reasonable for what you get.

üèõÔ∏è The museum itself:
It's huge, beautifully designed, and you could easily spend a whole day here. The exhibits cover Greek culture, history, and art, with incredible detail. Most of the statues and artifacts that were originally part of the Acropolis (or removed for preservation) are displayed here, so you're seeing the real treasures up close.

‚ú® What makes it special:
‚Ä¢	A chance to see pieces from the Acropolis that you won't find on the hill itself.
‚Ä¢	Exhibits that connect Greek history with the Roman era.
‚Ä¢	A modern, spacious museum that makes exploring easy and enjoyable.

Final thought: If you're visiting Greece, the Acropolis is a must - but the Acropolis Museum is just as important. It brings the history to life in ways the ruins alone can't. Strongly recommend making time for both.

Absolutely fascinating museum! The collection is well organized and gives a clear timeline of ancient civilizations in the region. The highlights for me were the pottery displays and the reconstructed statues - they really bring history to life.

The building itself is modern, clean, and well laid out, with plenty of signs in English (and other languages). There's also a small caf√© and a gift shop with unique, reasonably priced souvenirs.

Plan to spend at least 2‚Äì3 hours here if you want to take everything in. A must-visit while in Athens for history lovers and families alike.

reviews.text:
The Panathenaic Stadium in Athens is a must-visit for anyone interested in history, sport, or architecture. Entirely built from white marble, it's the only stadium of its kind in the world and famously hosted the first modern Olympic Games in 1896. Entry is ‚Ç¨10, and it's well worth it for the chance to walk in the footsteps of ancient and modern athletes alike.

The atmosphere is both grand and peaceful. Walking around the track is a surreal experience, especially imagining the roar of the crowd over a century ago. Climbing to the top of the stands offers fantastic views over the city-but be warned, it's very steep, so wear good shoes and take your time.

One of the most interesting features is the cool stone tunnel underneath the seating, which was used by athletes to enter the stadium. It feels like natural air conditioning and is a great spot to cool off on a hot day. It's also a great place to snap a few photos and soak in the historic vibe.

The small museum area inside displays Olympic torches and memorabilia, adding another layer to the visit. All in all, it's a unique site that combines beauty, history, and a real sense of awe. A true gem of Athens and well worth the time and entry fee.

Wow.
If you're interested in the history of the Olympic Games this is well worth visiting and at 10 Euro one of the cheaper attractions in Athens.
Make sure you visit the small, but interesting museum.
Unfortunately we couldn't go on the track because they were setting up for an event.
If you can brave the steep steps you will be rewarded with a great view of the Acropolis.

With just one full day in Athens, visiting the Panathenaic Stadium was at the top of my list -and it did not disappoint. The architecture is breathtaking, built entirely from marble and designed to transport you back to ancient times. Knowing it once held over 80,000 spectators -from everyday citizens to royalty -made standing there even more awe-inspiring.
The entrance fee is ‚Ç¨10, but with my UK student ID I was able to enter for ‚Ç¨5. Inside, the vaulted passage showcases fascinating artifacts from the very first Olympic Games to more recent ones, including medals and torches from across the generations.
I even ran a little race on the track (while chasing my hat that kept flying off in the wind!) -a playful and memorable moment that made the visit even more special.
Totally recommend adding this stop to your Athens adventure;it's history, culture, and fun all in one.

Situated near the Acropolis, this site holds great historical significance and was frequented by notable figures such as Sophocles and Protagoras.

The Temple of Hephaestus is one of the best-preserved ancient structures, offering a vivid glimpse into classical antiquity. Standing before it, you can almost picture life as it was centuries ago.

I thoroughly enjoyed my visit-it's the kind of place where time slips away, and you could easily spend hours exploring its history and atmosphere.

Temple of Hephaestus ‚Äì Athens' Hidden Gem

Tucked inside the Ancient Agora, the Temple of Hephaestus is one of the best-preserved ancient temples in Greece. Its elegant Doric columns and peaceful surroundings make it a perfect spot to soak in history without the crowds. Built between 460‚Äì420 BC, it's a quiet reminder of Athens' architectural brilliance. We loved how serene it felt-like stepping back in time.

I didn't knew if a visit of this place was worth 20‚Ç¨ per person but it truly was!
It's not just the incredible temple that you can visit but also a whole area with very interesting ruins and a museum in a historical building. It took us over 2 hours and we were happy about the visit.

places.generalDescription: The Holy Metropolitan Church of the Annunciation to the Virgin Mary, also known as Mitropoli Athinon, is a grand cathedral in Athens with a mix of Greco-Byzantine and neoclassical architecture. It holds significant religious and historical importance as the spiritual center of Greek Orthodoxy and has hosted important events such as royal weddings. The interior is equally impressive, featuring a museum in the crypt showcasing old Christian artifacts used in liturgy over the years.

sources.snippet: Although this may not be one of the most popular photo spots in Athens, it‚Äôs a great place to get unique pictures. reviews.text:
A Spiritual and Breathtaking Experience

It's honestly mind-blowing how beautiful this church is from the inside. The moment I stepped in, I felt a deep sense of peace and connection. The entire interior is a masterpiece - from the glowing candles to the inspiring paintings and the carefully arranged setup, every element speaks deeply to the heart of Christian tradition.

There is a powerful spiritual presence in this place that's hard to describe with words. It's the kind of church that makes you pause, reflect, and feel closer to God. I found myself standing in silence, just taking in the sacred atmosphere.

One suggestion I'd give is to improve the lighting inside. The artwork and details are absolutely stunning, but a bit more light would help visitors fully appreciate the beauty and craftsmanship that went into creating this space.

I truly loved this church and felt something very special there. May God bless everyone who visits it. Amen

I recently visited the Metropolitan Cathedral of Athens, and while it wasn't as massive or imposing as I expected for the capital city's main Orthodox church, it still left a deep impression. The space is relatively small, but incredibly ornate. The decor is rich with gold accents, beautiful icons, detailed woodwork, and intricate chandeliers. Every inch feels intentional and full of reverence. The lighting inside is quite low, which creates a very somber and contemplative atmosphere. It encourages you to slow down and take it all in.

One of the personnel inside the cathedral kindly informed me that there's a museum downstairs, which I would've missed otherwise. I paid a small fee of ‚Ç¨3 and was genuinely surprised by how impressive the collection was‚Ä¶ small but impressive. There were historical garments, staffs, headpieces, chalices, furniture, and other ceremonial objects used throughout the history of the Greek Orthodox Church. Everything was beautifully preserved and presented with care. While belonging to a different Christian denomination, it gave me a much deeper appreciation of the church's traditions and legacy.

Here are a few helpful tips that might be helpful for anyone planning to visit:
-Dress modestly, as this is an active place of worship
-Bring a few euros in cash for the museum downstairs
-Don't miss the chance to light a candle and pause for a quiet moment regardless of your faith background
-Visit during quieter times in the mid-morning or mid-afternoon for a more peaceful experience

Even though this cathedral isn't the most monumental or imposing structure in Athens, it has a quiet spiritual power and elegance that make it worth the visit. I'm really glad I made time for it. It's a special place that offers both historical insight and a calming space for reflection.

This is the biggest tourist attraction on Tino's but also for Greeks who come from all around their country to pay respect to the Virgin Mary. Many dedicated people crawl on their hands and knees up the hill for many blocks to enter into the church. Try to avoid any masses of you want to enter easily. Tickets are not needed. There is also a holy water fountain and beautiful cave of worship below the church. This is actually a Catholic Church (fun fact) not Orthodox

places.generalDescription: Technopolis City of Athens, situated in the vibrant Gazi neighborhood, is a former gasworks transformed into a cutting-edge hub for culture and technology. This dynamic space showcases the fusion of past and future through its museums, exhibitions, and educational programs. With over a million annual visitors, it's renowned for international festivals, contemporary art displays, and live music performances. The venue also features various historic buildings open to the public, offering a diverse range of experiences.

sources.snippet: The remains of the old gas factory give this neighborhood a completely different vibe than the rest of Athens. In the summer, there are a lot of outdoor events like markets and concerts. The surrounding area is one of the centers of Athenian nightlife, and you can also find astonishing murals on your way there.

places.name: Technopolis City of Athens

reviews.text:
Technopolis City of Athens is one of the most vibrant cultural venues in the heart of Athens, located in the Gazi district, right next to the Kerameikos metro station. Originally an old gas factory, the site has been transformed into a lively cultural hub, blending industrial heritage with modern creativity.

The architecture retains the original character of the 19th-century gasworks, giving the space a raw, authentic feel. The towering chimneys and preserved brick buildings provide a striking backdrop for a wide variety of events. From open-air concerts and electronic music festivals to exhibitions, markets, conferences, and children's events, Technopolis offers something for every interest and age.

One of its standout features is the Industrial Gas Museum, the only one of its kind in Greece, which offers an immersive journey through Athens' industrial past. Walking among old machinery and furnaces while learning about the gas factory's operation is both educational and unique.

The venue is accessible, well-maintained, and offers modern amenities without compromising its historical ambiance. There are plenty of caf√©s and food trucks during major events, and the open courtyards are perfect for relaxing with friends, even when no events are scheduled.

Technopolis also plays a major role in Athens' annual cultural life, hosting the Athens Technopolis Jazz Festival, the Athens Science Festival, and many more. The acoustics and lighting setup are generally excellent for outdoor performances, although sometimes overcrowding can be an issue during peak events.

Its central location makes it easily reachable by metro, bus, or even on foot from Monastiraki or Thissio. The surrounding area of Gazi is also full of restaurants, bars, and nightlife options, making Technopolis a great starting point or end to a fun evening out.

In short, Technopolis is a symbol of how Athens can successfully fuse its history with innovation. It's a must-visit destination for those interested in arts, history, or urban regeneration.

This was actually "Dinner in the Sky." This is where you're strapped in a chair, kinda like an amusement ride, then the entire table with the chef and wait staff are hoisted up in the air. They offer a welcome drink prior to seating if you get there early. It's all-inclusive while tip is extra. The food was delicious, and the fixed menu was great and perfectly paired with the local wine. The views from the top are amazing, and the entire table rotates slowly so that every person will have that perfect pic with the acropolis in the background.

sources.snippet: The Monastiraki square is a lively square in the middle of Athens. It‚Äôs great to find a rooftop-bar adjacent to it so that you can take an Instagram picture of this great spot. You‚Äôve got the square in the foreground, with the church of Pantanassa and the Acropolis all the way in the back.I took this picture from the rooftop bar MS Roof Garden.
sources.shortName: Instagram spots in Athens

sources.snippet: Overlooked by the Acropolis and with its sheeny mosaic pavement, Monastiraki Square juxtaposes the past with the present as older architecture stands alongside modern buildings. This lively square is home to a popular flea market, and it‚Äôs always bustling with people ‚Äî a great spot for people-watching. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: 10 of the most Instagrammable Places in Athens

sources.snippet: You‚Äôll find Monastiraki Square on the north side of the Acropolis, where the ancient and the new meet in the middle. The hustle and bustle make the little area a good spot if you prefer urban photography, but would like to include some of Athens‚Äô ancient feel into your photos as well.

sources.snippet: You can also find Panagia Pantanassa, one of the oldest churches in Athens, here. They also have a flea market and other outdoor vendors in Monastiraki Square. The place has a lot of energy and character, and it deserves a spot on my list of instagrammable places in Athens.

reviews.text:
A Greek Market Experience ‚Äì Food, Souvenirs & Local Vibes

This market reminded me a bit of the Central Market in Cambodia - lively, colorful, and full of energy. I really enjoyed the whole experience.

üç¥ The food: So many different restaurants and stalls to choose from, and everything we tried was tasty. Perfect spot if you want to sample a bit of everything.

üõçÔ∏è Souvenirs: Beyond food, there's plenty of shops selling souvenirs, so it's a great place to grab gifts or keepsakes after a meal.

üìç Location: Conveniently close to the Old Town and the Acropolis, so it's easy to combine with sightseeing.

üé∂ The vibe: Yes, it's a bit touristy, but still feels very Greek. You get the local spirit - music, chatter, and a warm atmosphere.

‚ú® Final thought: Whether you're there for food, shopping, or just soaking in the vibe, this market is an amazing experience you don't want to miss.

The Monastiraki Square is one of the most iconic and lively spots in Athens, Greece. Located in the historic center of Athens, the square is nearby to major landmarks such as the Acropolis, Ancient Agora, and Hadrian's Library.  It is easily accessible via Monastiraki Metro Station (lines 1 and 3).

Highlights of the square includes:
-  Monastiraki Flea Market: A bustling area filled with antique shops, souvenir stands, clothing, jewelry, and local crafts.
-  Tzistarakis Mosque: An 18th-century Ottoman mosque now functioning as a museum.
-  Hadrian's Library: Ancient Roman ruins right next to the square.

The square is usually crowded with people, both local and foreign. It also serves as a meeting point for tourists and locals alike.  There are many shops and tourists attractions here. A busy and lively place, which is a must visit for all tourists.

Fun shoppes and wonderful things to see. The atmosphere is lively with lots to stop and see. Impressive views and lovely places to visit, including the famous staircase, flea market and shoppes. Lots of places to stop and eat as well. Know that in Greece, you stop and enjoy each other and take your time eating. It's a social event not a fast paced activity.

places.generalDescription: Mount Lycabettus, also known as Lykavitos Hill, is a prominent limestone peak in Athens that offers breathtaking panoramic views of the city and the Aegean Sea. Visitors can reach the summit through a leisurely ascent on a funicular or by hiking through pine-scented pathways. The iconic Chapel of St. George awaits at the top, making it an ideal spot for nature enthusiasts, hikers, and photography enthusiasts.

sources.snippet: Although it's more than 300 feet taller than the Acropolis, Mount Lycabettus was fated to be Athens's other mountain: there's just not as much room at the top for a prominent temple complex. The presence of a tiny Greek Orthodox church might even be seen as a slight spiritual riposte to the pagan Parthenon. No matter, for it's a lovely urban peak with a great restaurant to boot, and the stupendous views stretch from city to sea.
sources.shortName: 10 of the Most Instagrammable Places in Athens

sources.snippet: Mount Lycabettus was one of our favourite photo location in Athens and the best place for views across the city. It is a limestone hill that rises above Athens and provides uninterrupted views across the city including the Acropolis and most of the major sites. It‚Äôs the highest point in the city and you can walk to the top of the hill, however, we recommend getting the funicular to the top and walking down to save some energy!
sources.siteName: The Whole World Is A Playground
sources.shortName: 13 Best Photo Locations in Athens (2024)

sources.snippet: Mount Lycabettus is one of the most popular places in Athens to get photos of the sunset, and looking above, you can see why. The Acropolis lights up like magic and you even get a pop of sea in the background, with some hills fringing the water. It‚Äôs pretty much the best Instagram spot in Athens, so be sure to reserve one of your nights to be spent watching the sunset from this beautiful mountain.
sources.shortName: Athens Instagram Inspiration: 15 Instagrammable Places in Athens

sources.snippet: Standing 277 meters above sea level, Lycabettus Hill is the highest point in central Athens. The view from Lycabettus Hill is best enjoyed at sunset whilst waiting for the lights of the Parthenon,  Temple of Olympian Zeus, and the Panathenaic Stadium to illuminate at dusk. You will also be reminded that Athens is surrounded by sea with spectacular views across the Aegean.
sources.shortName: PHOTOGRAPH THE ACROPOLIS - Find the Best Places in Athens

sources.snippet: Furthermore, you can get some great shots of Acropolis from Mount Lycabettus ‚Äì the highest place in Athens, see my point number 4. If you do not need to have Parthenon in the frame but you want to photograph the west part of Acropolis with the possibility to have rising sun in the frame, visit the Aeoropagus hill.
sources.shortName: 10 Places to Photograph in Athens, Greece

sources.snippet: For a sprawling view of Athens and the Acropolis, walk or take the Lycabettus Cable Car to the peak of Mount Lycabettus. From here, you get to see just how big this city is, with the Acropolis proudly rising up in the center from the low, white buildings. In the sunlight, this city literally sparkles.

sources.snippet: Without a doubt, the best spot for a view of Athens, Mount Lycabettus, is one of the best Instagram spots in Athens if you want to take photos of the sunset. You can either hike up there or take a cable car. There‚Äôs a tiny church which you can include in your photos as well.

reviews.text: View is definitely amazing during sunset, I recommend taking funicular which costs around 12 euros both ways (up and down). It is a bit crowded in the evening, but it is worth to visit to see capital Athens from above.

It's a little bit of a trek to get up to the top but once you do the views are priceless. The hike from the bottom was about 45 minutes with a few short breaks. It's definitely doable but be sure to bring some water along if it's a hot day to stay hydrated. There is a little cafe at the top to grab some drinks and snacks once you get there to refuel for the way down. It was a bit of a mission but was quite an experience to say the least.

Amazing Sunset here on top of the mountains, but the crowds there are too much can't really find a spot to take good photos, have to hike around 20-30min from the bottom , there is a restaurant OM the top as well

places.generalDescription: Little Kook is a popular fairytale-inspired cafe located in the Psirri neighborhood of Athens. The cafe is known for its whimsical decor, which changes with the seasons and is inspired by fairy tales such as Alice in Wonderland, Mary Poppins, Cinderella, and Peter Pan. This unique theme creates a magical atmosphere that delights visitors and provides plenty of opportunities for social media-worthy photographs.

sources.snippet: Located in the Psirri neighborhood, Little Kook lights up the narrow Pittaki alley with its flamboyant decorations inspired by fairy tales such as Alice in Wonderland, Mary Poppins, Cinderella and Peter Pan, immersing visitors in a fairy tale world. Because of its changing themes and decorations throughout the seasons, Little Kook has become a popular attraction in Athens and one of the most photographed cafes in the city. No matter what time of year you visit, the decorations will delight you!

sources.snippet: If you‚Äôre looking for Athens Instagram spots, then you can‚Äôt miss out on this place!. The cafe is decorated with the season meaning it changes throughout the year (e.g Halloween, Christmas, etc.) but no matter when you visit you‚Äôll be blown away.

Each corner is filled with charming details that spark joy and imagination. It's the perfect place to escape reality and indulge in a magical experience.

places.generalDescription: The Roman Forum of Athens, also known as the Roman Agora, was constructed by the Romans between 19-11 B.C. It served as a social and religious hub, as well as the focal point of city life in ancient Greece. Initially a place for political discussions and law-making, it later transformed into a bustling marketplace. The site features columns, an octagonal tower, two Roman Baths, a smaller theater, and an underground stoa.

sources.snippet: The Roman Agora is located on the north side of the Acropolis in the neighbourhood of Plaka. It was built during the Roman period in Athens and used to be one of the main meeting points in the city as well as housing the central market. I suggest taking a walk around the Agora to find cute photo opportunities.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Locations in Athens, Greece
17 Best Photo Spots in Athens: Most Beautiful Places + Map

sources.snippet: Located 363 meters from the Ancient Agora & North Side of the Acropolis. Not as spectacular and well preserved as the Ancient Agora, but still worth the visit. The Tower of the Winds is the most noteworthy structure known to be the earliest meteorological station.
sources.shortName: INSTAGRAM SPOTS IN ATHENS APART FROM THE ACROPOLIS

places.name: Roman Forum of Athens (Roman Agora)

reviews.text: If you're looking for another thing to visit in Athens, this is the one! Amazing place with beautiful trees as well. The museum is included in the ticket price, there are clean bathrooms,‚Ä¶ We paid 20 for an adult and this is definitely worth the price.

Not a ‚Äúmust see‚Äù in the Athens list of historical sites unless truly an aficionado, mainly as the other sites have so much more to see/learn from. The tower of the winds is interesting but you can't see inside all that well, and the site overall is more of a storage facility for pieces of marble from other sites. But it is only ‚Ç¨10 for entry and very quiet. And has a local tortoise.

A small, but interesting site within walking distance of the Acropolis and worth a visit, especially if you have the combi ticket that allows access to the Acropolis and others within Athens. Due to it being small, when we visited it was quiet too, to the point that we almost had the site to ourselves while wandering through the columns, which was particularly nice. Much like a few other sites, such as Hadrian's Library, most of the Roman Agora is visible from the surrounding streets, so even if you don't have a ticket, you can still enjoy it.

places.generalDescription: The Philopappos Monument, built in the 2nd century AD, is a tomb and monument dedicated to Gaius Julius Antiochus Filopappos, a prominent Roman figure. It is located on Philopappou Hill and offers stunning views of Athens and the port of Piraeus. The monument features ancient chiseled friezes and inscriptions.

sources.snippet: The entrance to the park is at the roundabout where the buses park ‚Äì opposite the road that leads to the ticket booth. As you walk up the main paved promenade inside the park, follow the sign to Philopappos Monument. The walking paths are well worn and you‚Äôll meet other tourists along the way, so you can‚Äôt get lost.
sources.shortName: THE ACROPOLIS and where to take the best photographs

places.name: Philopappos Monument

reviews.text:
You can see this monument easily from the Acropolis, and as you can imagine it's a great place to get photos of the western side of the Acropolis in return! A hilly walk but shaded on the way up/down, it rewards you with a lovely viewpoint from the top. The monument itself is less interesting but has information.
I'd recommend walking up the steeper north side (past Socrates prison cave) to enjoy a slower walk down to the west for more viewpoints as you go.
Go up there for the views. The monument is just a bonus. This is one of the best spots in all of athens. You will not get better views of the Acropolis.

Great views of the Parthenon and acropolis. A good little hike up which was nice to stretch your legs. Know that most of the trails are unmarked and a bit of a maze but it's hard to get lost getting up or down. It's also very dusty. Know that a lot of the trails are dirt. Great views of overall Athens as well though.

places.generalDescription: The Erechtheion is a famous ancient Greek temple located in the Acropolis complex of Athens. Built between 421 and 406 B.C., it was dedicated to Athena and Poseidon, featuring a porch with six caryatids. This Ionic-style temple served as a place for Athenians to worship various Greek gods, including Erechtheus, the mythical king of Athens.

sources.snippet: These will guide you to the magnificent Acropolis, the highlight of the city of Athens with the imposing buildings of Parthenon, the Erechtheion, Propylaea, and the Temple of Nike, as you explore the highest hill of the city. This is the best time to have your camera ready and fill those memory cards with magnificent panoramic views of Athens from the top scenic location spots like Filoppapos, Mars, and Pnyx.
sources.shortName: Best photo spots in Athens

sources.snippet: Erechtheion is part of the Acropolis, making up the Porch of the Caryatids with six gorgeously carved figures making up columns of this beautiful temple. It‚Äôs a unique place in the Acropolis and people won‚Äôt be crawling all over it the way they will be for the Parthenon. To get this shot, you‚Äôll want a zoom lens that is capable of capturing detail at this level ‚Äì we‚Äôd recommend at least a 200mm zoom.
sources.shortName: Athens Instagram Inspiration: 15 Instagrammable Places in Athens

places.name: Erechtheion

reviews.text: Absolutely stunning! My favourite temple within the Acropolis of Athens. The statues of Athena are replicas. You can find the original statues within the Acropolis Museum. Love the olive tree outside of the temple, it adds so much to meaning of what it is.

The Erechtheion is one of the most fascinating temples on the Acropolis, smaller than the Parthenon but full of character and history. Famous for its Porch of the Caryatids, with the elegant sculpted maidens supporting the roof, it's an unforgettable example of classical Greek art and architecture. Built between 421‚Äì406 BCE, the temple is tied to important myths, including the legendary contest between Athena and Poseidon for the patronage of Athens. Standing here, you really feel the blend of myth, history, and beauty that defines the Acropolis.

‚ú® Travel Tips:
‚Ä¢	üéü Access is included in the Acropolis ticket, which also covers the Parthenon and other nearby monuments.
‚Ä¢	üï∞ Visit early in the morning or later in the day to avoid crowds and heat.
‚Ä¢	üì∏ The Caryatids are stunning, but note that the ones on the temple are replicas; the originals are housed in the Acropolis Museum nearby.
‚Ä¢	üëü Wear good walking shoes, the paths around the Acropolis are uneven and slippery in places.
‚Ä¢	üåÖ For magical views, linger near the Erechtheion close to sunset, when the marble glows beautifully.

I was most thrilled to see the Erechtheion, a temple dedicated to both Athena and Poseidon, out of the entire ground of Acropolis. The six maidens, Caryatids, standing in silent grace on the south side of the porch rain or shine, who took the place of columns in supporting the entablature, was definitely the reason I came. In 1978, severely weathered and affected by pollution, five caryatids were removed to the Acropolis Museum and replaced with replicas. The other caryatid, the second from the left in the front row of four, was appropriated by Lord Elgin, who between 1801 and 1805, removed about half of the surviving sculptures from the fallen ruins of the Acropolis and from the Parthenon itself.  They were acquired by the British Museum 1816 and put on public display the following year.

The term Caryatids is derived from the town of Karyai in the Peloponnese, where young women perform dances in honor of a local goddess Artemis. These figures, with their elegant stances and meticulously carved drapery, showcase their Ancient Greeks' mastery over marble. Each figure is distinct, with its own posture and drapery, hinting at individual personalities and a high level of details.

In the story as handed down by the architect Vitruvius, Caryatids were punished by the Greeks for siding with the Persians during the 2nd Persian War in 480 BC., and were thus obliged to carry on their heads the weight of their cloths and jewelry.

The Caryatids symbolize not only their strength but also their roles as intermediaries between the heavens and the earth. The dual function highlights the Ancient Greek belief in the harmony between beauty and utility.

places.generalDescription: Syntagma Square is the vibrant heart of Athens, where history and culture converge in a lively atmosphere. This expansive, tree-lined square features charming cafes and park benches, making it an ideal spot to relax. Dominating the landscape is the Hellenic Parliament building, where visitors can marvel at the ceremonial Changing of the Guard performed by evzones in their striking traditional attire.

sources.snippet: Continuing your Athens sightseeing Tour around the city, don‚Äôt miss out on taking your photos of other major Athens sites, including the Greek Parliament, the Syntagma square, the National Garden, the St. Paul‚Äôs Church, the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, the Catholic Cathedral, the Schliemann‚Äôs House, the University of Athens, the Academy of Athens, and the National Library. However, we do suggest a photo stop at Panathinaiko Stadium where the first Olympic Games took place in 1896, as It is the only stadium built out of white marble. For more majestic images of breathtaking Athenian views you can take our Cape Sounio Half Day Afternoon Tour.
sources.shortName: Best photo spots in Athens

sources.snippet: Syntagma, or Constitution Square, is the ground zero of Athens. It was named that way because the Greek people demanded from their King the drafting of a constitution for the newly established state right in that square. Today there is no King and the beautiful neoclassic building in Syntagma square houses the Greek Parliament.
sources.shortName: The Top 30 Photo Locations in Athens

sources.snippet: It‚Äôs a busy central square with a nice park, a fountain, and lots of shops. The square itself is instagrammable, but you should also stay for the change of guards in front of the parliament. The ceremony happens every hour on the hour, it‚Äôs free, and it lasts only 10-15 minutes.

sources.snippet: The centre of modern Athens is arguably the Syntagma Square. The square is dominated by the view towards the Parliament building. On the other side of the square, the main shopping Ermou street begins.

sources.snippet: This is a central square in the city and is the location where the political activity takes place. You can head to this location on Sundays to capture pictures of the changing of the guards process.

sources.snippet: The Public store by Syntagma Square turns into a giant present as it covered its store with lights depicting a box with bow.

places.name: Syntagma Square

reviews.text: Pretty busy square located in the center of Athens. This place will most likely be your first attraction you see in Athens after getting down from the X95 Airport Bus. There are some amazing photo angles up on the stairs looking towards the city. You can also enjoy a full view of the Hellenic Parliament (Former Royal Palace). Make sure to check out the "changing-of-the-guards" event at the Hellenic Parliament every hour!

A beautiful and lively part of Athens. I went in August; there was live music and plenty of both tourists and locals enjoying the ambience. Very busy but amazing vibes! In front of the parliament and near beautiful hotels. The metro station is right here, as well as bus stops going to the airport and other destinations. In the daytime, there's also places to sit down in the shade when it's hot.

Syntagma Square and Ermou Street form the vibrant heart of Athens and are absolutely worth a visit, especially during the late afternoon hours when the heat begins to ease. Syntagma is not only historically important-with the Parliament building and the famous Changing of the Guard ceremony-but also a great starting point for exploring the city.
Right next to it, Ermou Street stretches out as one of Athens' busiest shopping streets, lined with a fantastic mix of international brands, Greek fashion stores, and small boutiques. Whether you're looking for clothes, shoes, souvenirs, or just browsing, there's something for everyone. The street is pedestrian-friendly and shaded in some parts, making it a pleasant walk even in warm weather.
There are also plenty of cafes, bakeries, and juice bars along the way if you need to cool off with a drink or grab a quick bite. Street performers and local musicians often add to the lively atmosphere, making the whole experience even more enjoyable.
If you're visiting Athens, this area should definitely be on your list-great for shopping, relaxing, people-watching, and feeling the energy of the city. It's where ancient charm meets modern Athenian life.

places.generalDescription: Varvakios Central Municipal Market in Athens is a bustling hub where locals shop for fresh fish, meat, and produce. The historic market is filled with the fragrant aroma of Greek ingredients and lively butchers vying for your attention. You can also find food stalls offering traditional Greek dishes like gyro, souvlaki, feta cheese, and Greek salad. Additionally, the market features restaurants serving authentic Greek mezethes at reasonable prices.

sources.snippet: We love photographing food markets and the Central Agora is a great option in Athens. The market is located around 10 minutes walk from the Plaka and is open Monday through Saturday from around 8am to 8pm. The market has great opportunities for photography and the selection of meat, fish and produces on display is one of the best we‚Äôve seen in Europe.

sources.snippet: The vast central market is composed of stands selling meat, produce, and ‚Äî given Athens‚Äô location on the Aegean Sea‚Äôs Saronic Gulf ‚Äî plenty of seafood. Take a stroll through the day‚Äôs catch and savor a meal or a snack. View this post on Instagram

reviews.text: Really nice this market. It's very organised and tidy. You may find it very interesting if you are a nuts / seafood / herbs lover, as majority of these grocery are fairly cheap. In general, it's really a nice place to feel local Greek culture and food.

A really interesting market to walk through!! We have nothing like this at home in Canada that I could compare to, so as a visitor to Athens it was amazing to walk through and see something like this.   It was amazing to see what they sell and how they use all parts of the animal.  Very busy place with locals.

places.generalDescription: The Acropolis in Athens is a must-see for families, especially if kids are familiar with Greek mythology. A visit to the city center should include a climb up the rocky Acropolis hill and a stop at the new Acropolis museum. Nearby attractions like the temple of Zeus and Plaka neighborhood offer more historical and cultural experiences. The city also boasts other notable sites such as The Oracle at Delphi, Ancient Agora, Monastiraki, Meteora, and more.

sources.snippet: At 512 feet tall and crowned by the Parthenon ‚Äî built in 438 BC ‚Äî the Acropolis may well be the world's coolest flattop. According to UNESCO, the Acropolis and its monuments "are universal symbols of the classical spirit and civilization and form the greatest architectural and artistic complex bequeathed by Greek Antiquity to the world." It's debatable what has greater Instagram appeal, the ancient ruins themselves or the panoramic views over Athens, but in any case don't forget to inspect the Propylaia (the monumental entranceway) and Erechtheion temple on the north side. A post shared by Lorena (@lorenavaseluk) on Mar 6, 2018 at 10:14am PST
sources.shortName: 10 of the Most Instagrammable Places in Athens

sources.snippet: You will first want to capture the heart of the city by discovering ancient Athens‚Äô most spectacular sights and iconic landmarks with our Athens City Tour & Acropolis Museum. Visit the most photogenic Hadrian‚Äôs Arch and the Temple of the Olympian Zeus. places.name: Acropolis

reviews.text: The Acropolis is a must see and the best historical site available in Athens in my opinion.  We spent close to 3 hours exploring everything.  There are educational signs throughout explaining what you are seeing and often with drawings depicting what it would have looked like when newly built.  The views of Athens are amazing.  You can see all the way to the sea.  Look up occasionally and watch the birds wheeling in the sky.  There is a constant breeze on the upper side which is wonderful in July.  I would recommend close toed shoes with good tread.  Lots of rock and uneven spots.  Not appropriate for a stroller.  There is an elevator on the North side for people with disabilities.  Bathrooms are only located at the base.  One complaint is that you do not find out that areas are closed until you get to them.  There were not any signs alerting to a change.

This was a beautiful experience!

I will warn you that there's a lot of steps‚Ä¶ so be prepared! Right now Greece is SO hot that you need to go early in the morning. We waited until 6 PM to go and it was a bit unbearable! Bring lots of water with you, and wear really sturdy shoes for climbing hills. (I saw a lady bring walking sticks‚Ä¶ And that was incredibly smart on her part!)

But it's too amazing to miss, it's one of those iconic landmarks that is a must see! So even if you can only go in the evening, still go!

The walkway is a bit slippery going uphill, but coming back down, you do a different route‚Ä¶ And thankfully that wasn't slippery at all.

The Acropolis ‚Äì A Once-in-a-Lifetime Dream in Athens

Finally, I got to visit the Acropolis in Greece - and it honestly still feels like a dream. To stand on this ancient site, surrounded by the legacy of the Greek Empire, was one of the most unforgettable experiences of my life.

üèõÔ∏è The architecture & history: The temples, the ruins, the sheer scale of the place‚Ä¶ it blows you away. The history here is so rich, you can feel it in every stone. We even explored the Theater of Dionysus (Temple of Music), which was incredible to see in person.

üåÑ The views: From the top, you get a panoramic view of Athens - the entire city spreads out beneath you, framed by olive groves and historic landmarks.

üï∞Ô∏è The experience: The Acropolis is huge - we spent more than half a day there and still felt like we only scratched the surface. There are so many temples, paths, and corners to explore, each with its own story.

Tip: The stones are slippery from all the tourist traffic, so take care when walking. Honestly, with how many people visit, I wouldn't be surprised if one day access becomes more restricted - so if you have the chance, go while you can.

‚ú® Final thought:
Visiting the Acropolis is truly a once-in-a-lifetime experience. The history, the architecture, the views - all of it makes this site a must-see if you're ever in Greece. Strongly recommend.

places.generalDescription: The Temple of Athena Nike, located on the southwest corner of the Acropolis in Athens, is an ancient Ionic temple dedicated to the goddess Athena. Built between 432 and 421 BC to replace a previous temple destroyed by the Persians, it features four imposing monolithic columns and adorned marble slabs. This was a place where citizens would come to pray to the goddess Nike, a form of Athena associated with victory, particularly during times of war.

reviews.text:
Slippery. Really slippery surface. From the parking lot, it's an easy but uphill walk. Got a little congested with visitors at the top, but the ruins are magnificent to experience in person and well worth the effort.
Just exercise every caution walking on the slick marble path up&down. Minimal shade, bring water.

The most famous of the acropolises is the Acropolis of Athens, which is today an archaeological reserve with a museum and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Actually, it is a hill 156 m high, 170 m wide and about 300 m long[1].
The Parthenon, the main temple of Ancient Athens in honor of the patroness of the city and all of Attica, the goddess Athena, has survived to this day; the Propylaea and the remains of the Pinakothek (a collection of paintings-pinakes), the Temple of Nike Apteros (Wingless Victory) by the architect Callicrates.

The Temple of Athena Nike, standing on the southwest bastion of the Acropolis, is the smallest but one of the most refined monuments of the Periclean building program. Completed around 420 BC and dedicated to Athena as the goddess of victory, it welcomed visitors ascending to the sacred plateau, symbolizing the hope for Athenian triumph during the Peloponnesian War.

This elegant Ionic temple was designed by the architect Kallikrates and is distinguished by its harmonious proportions and graceful simplicity. Despite its modest size, the monument embodied the sophistication of classical architecture. Its friezes depicted historical and mythological battles, celebrating both divine power and human courage, while reinforcing Athens' identity as a leading city-state.

The temple's most celebrated feature was the balustrade that once surrounded it, adorned with reliefs of winged figures known as Nikai. Among them, the famous ‚ÄúNike Adjusting Her Sandal‚Äù remains one of the most exquisite examples of classical relief sculpture, combining naturalism with delicate elegance.

Today, the Temple of Athena Nike stands as a universal symbol of victory, freedom, and cultural achievement. As part of the UNESCO World Heritage site of the Acropolis, it continues to inspire admiration, embodying both the resilience of Athens and the timeless beauty of classical art.
